response.answer_text: No. A fixation on tracking our growth and capabilities using a standardized grading scale gets implanted in us at an early age. By the time we reach adulthood, many people simply accept this as the only method to gauge what we can accomplish. That’s a huge problem – because grades and intelligence are two very different things. There’s a popular quote that’s floated around the internet for years. “If you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life believing that it is stupid.” Unfortunately, the way we evaluate peoples’ skills and abilities makes about as much sense as judging a fish by its climbing ability. Reasons your grades do not define your intelligence 1.) Grades don’t necessarily reflect your abilities. You might know the lessons covered in class, but still be unable to translate that into performance once it’s up for a grade. For example, a lot of people suffer from test anxiety. That can make it difficult to succeed – no matter how well you understand the material. If you’re stressed or anxious, your brain will want to do a thousand things other than complete a complex assignment. So don’t be surprised if a person underperforms on a task; maybe they are too stressed to focus. 2.) Grades are less important than comprehension. If you study to memorize material for a test…well…congrats, you’ve learned to take that test. It doesn’t mean you’ve learned the material, though. Facts and stats simply spilled onto a page without much context or need for deeper problem solving. This approach cannot accurately measure abilities. In fact, you might as well just play a game of Simon. 3.) You can’t always quantify your strengths. As humans, we’re a lot more than just numbers on a page. Each of us has an incredible variety of different strengths and talents. The abilities typically measured by grades only cover a set range of them. Intelligence is just one of countless variables that will impact your grades. 4.) There are different kinds of intelligence. Imagine you have three people: aphysicist, an expert historian, and amaster artist. Each one is brilliant in their own.But if you measure them according to the skillsets of the other two, they might all look unremarkable when you grade their papers. It’s just like that quote we talked about earlier. 5.) Your passion matters more. Intelligence refers to one’s ability to learn to understand, and apply knowledge and skills. But it doesn’t count for much if you don’t have the drive to do any of those things. If you’re studying something you don’t care about, you’re not likely to invest much energy in trying to comprehend it. Thus, a person with passion that pushes them forward is more likely to come out ahead of someone who might be a genius, but who isn’t motivated. That’s not to say you won’t be dedicating time and energy to some things you don’t really care about. But if you can identify what you are passionate about, you can learn to follow paths that will play to your strengths rather than your weaknesses. 6.) Intelligence can still change. By engaging in exercises to train your mind over time you can boost your intelligence and shape your own reality. Bottom Line No one system could ever define your overall intelligence. This realization goes two ways: just as grades don’t dictate your intelligence, your intelligence also does not dictate your grades.

Not really. Intelligent people may get good grades, or they may not. Not all classes are based on logic or intelligence. More importantly not all teachers can deal with smart kids. I used to “skip” steps and not “show my work” all of the time in my math class. My teach gave me a D on a test when I got 100% of the answers correct. The next test I was pissed, so on the back I drew a brain and write “I figured it out in my head because I am not stupid like you.” It didn’t go well for me that day. I won’t fling out all of my dirty laundry, but in many ways that teach was a contribute to why I had a hard time with school instead of getting a free ride to any school I wanted. In the end, people with Genius level IQs actually have a higher drop out rate than normal peeps. I believe my personal experience reflects a lot of the reasons why, and most of them are solvable. The biggest two reasons I see, could be easily solved by investing a little money or time or even a little effort on teachers. Boredom: We need to challenge students that exceed the normal students, not ignore them. This is something I have seen some improvement on over the past two decades, but it not enough.Outcast (don’t fit in): If we take the smarter kids and put them in “smart schools” they will fit in better, they will challenge each other, have teachers that are trained specifically on dealing with smart kids. Unfortunately for the US, we are so caught up in ideas like no child left behind instead of ideas like, promote the geniuses for a better future. As such we devote more money to those with learning issues and ignore those who can actually change the world. I am not saying we should not help out all children, but instead of neglecting the bright students, we need to push them to be even better. As such we need to restructure our education system, moving smart children into focused schools where they can excel without the pressures put on by normal students. Yes they need to learn how to deal with normal people, but that is what college is for. When even the normal kids are focused on learning (well some anyways). This is in no way to suggest we should detract money from those in need, we need to really fund education properly or become an obsolete country. We should double our education budget. Instead we get a majority party that wants to reduce public education to a joke, with short sighted views. With resources such as Perry Preschool Study - HighScope we have all of the evidence needed to show that spending a little on education today will have huge gains for the future (Especially in reduced crime).

No. Let me repeat that, No. There are many factors which are significantly more important for the grades than intelligence.  Time and Discipline. The hours one puts in studying a subject is the most important piece. In my experience, whoever studies more is the one who gets the better grades.Motivation. I experienced that whenever I have a good reason to get a top grade — i.e. not just an ego-boost — I can deliver. Furthermore, if I like the thing I am studying, my brain automatically makes it easier for me to understand that subject.Concentration. Can you avoid distractions? Are you worrying about your private life? Is your neighbor beating on the wall? Focusing is also a skill. The people who can concentrate more generally produce much higher results.Cheating. I do not mean cheating in the general sense. But most exams require you to know how to take the exam. Some people understand the subject fundamentally yet still are unable to write the exam properly. To get absolutely top grades, you need to be also trained.Familiarity with the material. This is generally ignored. Having experience with, say, physics will enable you to understand and study further topics much easier even if they are not directly linked to the previous topics you learned. That is because you already developed intuition for the subject.Of course, intelligence is linked to some of these. You can argue that a more intelligent person will learn how to “cheat” easier or that he or she might be more focused than a less intelligent person. I am not denying that there is a correlation between grades and intelligence but it’s not necessarily a causation nor do “grades determine intelligence”. Aside from these, I am familiar with many top graders in Cambridge and back in my high school and people whom I find brilliant. In my experience, these brilliant people often do not achieve top grades — this is, of course, linked to several factors.

Well…. I don't think so. Let's take an instance. You 're a brilliant student with all-round skills. Another student, let's assume that's I, who knows only physics/maths/art/sport. ( your choice to choose the subject for me.) You will try to be the best in every subject. You will learn all the books of the course and your session will be over. Congrats! You've got the best grades. Now, what did I do in that time? Being the best only in my preferred and most favorite subject, i spent my time studying and imagining all about it. I gave 50%,both my time and hard work to my subject and the rest 50% to other subjects and other chorus or work. I got not-so-good result. This scenario went on for many years. After schooling, You don't know what to do now. You think of the field you’re best at. After an year or two(it may take a lot more time) of thinking and trying different things, you still don't get to the result. With the guidance of your parents, you get admitted to a college or university of your parent's wish. You don't get along well there because that's not what you would have thought to do. But still for your parents, you do that. After that, you find a job with your degree and some other things. Or You give civil services exams or government exams and get enrolled into government jobs. (That's what most of the Indian parents want their child to do this ensure the rest of their life). After 10 years You are watching news and get astonished seeing me on the television. I have become a famous personality. (Well I know that's too much serialistic but isn't it interesting.) Now, you are flashing your memory 10 years back. Thinking about me. I, with a wavy future in front of my eyes, but a stable mind with my best ability, got enrolled in making a history and not with my school grades. I didnot choose the regular and ordinary path. Instead,I chose an adventurous path. Getting ahead by taking some risks. And I finally did what I wanted to. Moral: Until you take risks and do something, you are not intelligent. Just reading and learning your coursebooks doesn't make you intelligent. It's you yourself who identifies the area of intelligence inside you. Taking the knowledge from everywhere is not really worth. Grades and exams have no connection with your intelligence. Do whatever you like. Don’t cram up with your course books. Bringing a good result is a child's play. A little practice and you too can top the class! But does it defines someone's intelligence? No.. Not at all. Every one is intelligent but in different fields. Someone's intelligent in science, someone in math, someone in art,or the other in sports. If you try to be intelligent in every of the above mentioned subjects( and more), you 'll get dumb in your best subject. And that's one of the major cons of our grading system and our parent's thinking system. They link the grades of exams with our intelligence.

OK, that is a very good question. The biggest misconception about marks and intelligence is that they are equivalent to each other: if you have one then you must have the other. Unfortunately, they are not. Grades measure your performance in school, while intelligence measures your performance in life in general.You might know yourself that in school, you are given the material then tested on it. But in life, you are given the test first. Your challenge in school is to mentally ingest as much knowledge as possible to excel on tests. Your challenge in life is to find the right information, look at big pictures, and take the steps you think are right. Your good grade on a test measures your success in school, while the positive impact on your life resulting from a decision you've made measures your success in life. The reason why you were left thinking for a little bit is because you started to realize the difference between school and life. Yes, there is quite a difference! College resembles real life more than K1-12. That is why most students find it challenging to adjust. Like I mentioned before that finding the right information is a common challenge in life, but some of the knowledge you gather in school will serve you later. It will not serve you in all circumstances, however. You have to get out there and learn the hard way sometimes. To sum it up: Intelligence is a broad measurement of performance that includes good grades, but they are not the only thing. Those peers of yours that claim you are not smart are mistaken. you are smart because you have found a way to excel at what you want, in this case it is school. It is the desire to succeed that drives you in the direction of success in any of your endeavors.

No. Grades determine work ethic, nothing else.  Work ethic favours stupidity over intellect.Only for “stupid” work, an employer cares about work ethic, like McDonalds or janitor.Work ethic doesn't make you get a promotion any quicker.Work ethic doesn't show discipline. People think it does. It is more blind discipline.Work ethic doesn't prove an employer any you are useful, if you have dick for brains, you get the interview based on your grades, but not the job.I've seen my fair share of CVs in my life. If I've seen one trend over the last few years is that I see more people with higher grades than ever before, but more dick for brain than I've ever seen. Sometimes this stupidity hurts. This is why we have interviews, so I can filter that out.. Ultimately, I don't see much value in a A* university degree, nor in tens of certificates. When I see 20 graduates in an assessment centre, it's easy to tell which ones got there by wasting hours in the library and which ones got there by sheer intellect.  Obviously when you hire a team of graduates, you do pick one of the blind work ethic like a horse graduates. Because sometimes you want to hang out with people who aren't that bright, just to see how the other half lives.

Short answer - Grades DO NOT determine intelligence. From your question, I understand that you are not satisfied with a math test that you attempted. And, based on this you have reached a deep dilemma whether your grades will determine intelligence. Grade of a particular test only tells how well you performed with the set of questions that were asked and at that particular time. So, a person who achieves the highest grade in a test is not guaranteed to reach the same grade if a different set of questions are posed. So, how can one say that grades determine intelligence? My God! The two are unrelated things. You are still in high school, and you have got lot of examinations to pass through (academically or otherwise). And in the course, you, like every other human will face failures and hardships too. But, you should look at them as points of learning and move on to the next examination with improved zeal. More importantly, you have written that you have a liking for mathematics. I would advise you to focus on learning the subject rather than grades. If you put your 100% efforts, everything will fall in place. This does not mean that I am asking you to ignore grades and move on. You must try to get good grades too. Its unfortunate that in this competitive world, your collective grades show your sincerity of efforts. All the best!

Let’s say you’re Mr-Smarty-Pants Jr. You wake up to a shining morning, you look at the mirror and say: —Oh my, what a handsome smart man. You sit for some coffee and there’s a crossword, being the smart little stud that you are, you think to yourself: —I’ll solve this shit in my mind and THEN I’ll write it in one fell swoop. Logically, the crossword falls over to your dazzling performance. This is certainly no match for you. Life has to have some meaningful challenges around. It is fitting then to play around with every-day activities while adding entertaining small twists. You write words in reverse order, read them backwards, forwards, mirrored, and else. School, needless to say, is NO challenge for you. Exams last no-time, homework gets solved in class, explanations need to be given once. You help the teacher explaining things to your classmates. Exam time approaches, and you’re more than ready: you were BORN ready. The date is due this afternoon and you feel you don’t need to study. YOU KNOW YOU’RE RIGHT, and the Universe knows too. Anyways, life is good, you’re good, everything’s ok. You are playing your crosswords-without-ink game when the TV in the background says: —BREAKING NEWS. Structural damage on main highway bridge. Casualties in the dozens. The last word in the crossword gets written and you raise your eyes to the TV. —What the fuck is mom’s car doing right there? OH MY GOD. NO. A picture of a car with enormous amounts of debris on top of it appears. The license plate is your mom’s. Paramedics and rescuers are all over the place. You’re smart, you know there’s no way she’s alive. Yet you find excuses, you desperately try to believe this isn't real, that it is a bad joke, a bad dream. A nightmare. Now your mom is dead and you've got an exam to take in about two hours. How can you possibly perform well? No sane person will ALLOW you to take that exam in the first place. Replace personal tragedy with malnutrition, depression, anxiety, child abuse and more; and you’ll definitely see why someone can under-perform a test because of external influences.

Jesus christ no. Seriously? Equating being a good doggie within an institution to actual intelligence is ridiculous. How do you get top grades? Study a lot, cheat, get your grades curved, or a combination of those 3 makes up 95% of the people in the education system. Likewise do all the doggie points that have nothing to do with your knowledge like show up to class and turn in homework assignments. Alternatively if you’re intuitively intelligent, you can study very little, none at all sometimes, and merely go to class. A lot of the time this will actually cause intelligent individuals to not want to waste time with doggie points like showing up to class or turning in homework. The problem is there’s no way to tell which is which and who got there in what way. If you want proof that getting top grades doesn’t necessarily mean you’re intelligent look up one of the Reps from New York named Alexandria Ocasio Cortez (yes a US congresswoman). She has a degree in economics and international relations cum laude. That means she got a high GPA. She doesn’t know the definition of unemployment and she thinks you fund programs by printing money. World class economist.

No single thing “defines” a person’s intelligence. Intelligence is far too nebulous and complex for something as one-dimensional as grades to accurately determine. It wouldn’t even be accurate to say that grades measure how hard you work. Grades measure how well someone has grasped a given set of concepts. They reflect your understanding (and potentially your weaknesses). That being said, I’m just as annoyed by the claim “School is just about memorization, not learning. Grades don’t determine intelligence” as I am by the 4.0 cult. It seems that people who consider themselves intelligent but aren’t doing well in school say this to convince themselves that they’re smart. You may be very smart even if you’re failing chemistry*, I get that. But you’re conflating intelligence with understanding. Intelligence is broadly defined as the capacity for reasoning and learning, not the act of understanding itself. *I’m almost failing chemistry, which is why I used it as an example. Don’t take it personally.

No. Grades determine work ethic, nothing else.  Work ethic favours stupidity over intellect.Only for “stupid” work, an employer cares about work ethic, like McDonalds or janitor.Work ethic doesn't make you get a promotion any quicker.Work ethic doesn't show discipline. People think it does. It is more blind discipline.Work ethic doesn't prove an employer any you are useful, if you have dick for brains, you get the interview based on your grades, but not the job.I've seen my fair share of CVs in my life. If I've seen one trend over the last few years is that I see more people with higher grades than ever before, but more dick for brain than I've ever seen. Sometimes this stupidity hurts. This is why we've interviews, and so I can filter that out.. Ultimately, I do not see much worth in a A* university degree, nor in tens of certificates. Once I see 20 students in an assessment centre, you can tell which ones got indeed there by wasting hours in the collection and which ones got there by sheer intellect.  Obviously whenever you employ a team of students, you are doing choose one of blind work ethic like a horse graduates. Because sometimes you want to hang out with people who aren't that bright, just to see how the other half lives.

Honestly? It ranges from a lot to not at all, depending on the type of education and the type of intelligence you are referring to. Getting good grades in school isn’t necessarily based on intelligence in the traditional sense, but rather a measure of knowing what teachers want, or knowing the system. From personal experience, some of my peers are rather bright, slick even, but they don’t get good grades merely because they can’t be arsed to put in the effort. Thus, bringing me to my next point, good grades are also a measure of studiousness. There are three types of people that thrive in school, which I have concluded from my years of high school, ones that are intelligent, ones that work hard, ones that are intelligent and work hard. Now, like I’ve mentioned before, some intelligent people undermine hard work. This would relate to the type of education a high school offers, some require influxes of work to be done, others require just enough to test the character of the student. There is no definite answer to your question as there are many factors to be considered, but hopefully this gives you somewhat of an opinion from a current high school student.

I am not sure about the the past (in context to Indian education system); but, grades certainly do not determine intelligence anymore. The reason being privatisation of education system! The private schools/institutions are far too generous in giving marks to their students. I know that in most of the private schools teachers are forced to give marks far too generously as the management want good results. I have seen answer sheets of many students (10th class, board examination), many of them won't even pass if the marks were given on merits; but, the instruction comes to the teachers through principal (by management) that they should ignore mistakes of students and if they have written anything in answer sheets, they should be given marks (even if they have written wordings of a song for an answer)! Now, if they were to be evuated like we were in government schools, most of them won't even pass (I am not talking about all private school as there are some really good private schools as well, but majority of the private schools now are not worth it); but, in private schools, these students are pushed to around 60–70% marks and the one who would have got 60–70% marks (with fair evaluation) are pushed into Ninties. Privatisation of educational institutions has done more bad than good to education in general. The pressure is on teachers to come up with good results, they are asked to allow students to cheat or help them in examination as schools want better results to get more admission in the next session. We are playing with the future of these kids who are made to believe that they are best and are fooled by benevolently higher grades given to them, in believing that they know everything. I think we seriously need to look into the education industry before it is too late.

Not necessarily, but sometimes they reflect success. I taught lots of kids who frustrated me because they wouldn't apply themselves and I knew they could be such gifted students. When you have great grades, you oftentimes get into better colleges, make better contacts when networking and ultimately, get better jobs. But, having said that, you are a different animal. If you are trying your best and getting B and C grades it bodes well for your work ethic. I got B's and C's in school, went to college later in life and graduated with a 3.74. A dedicated person who works to his potential can be very knowledgeable is his/her field, or life in general. Don't be ashamed of B's and C's. You are probably a teacher's dream. If you try hard, do your work, are attentive in class, that's all anyone can ask. That's the markings of a good student and productive adult.

No. Grades determine work ethic, nothing else.  Work ethic favours stupidity over intellect.Only for “stupid” work, an employer cares about work ethic, like McDonalds or janitor.Work ethic doesn't make you get a promotion any quicker.Work ethic doesn't show discipline. People think it does. It is more blind discipline.Work ethic doesn't prove an employer any you are useful, if you have dick for brains, you get the interview based on your grades, but not the job.I've seen my fair share of CVs in my life. If I've seen one trend over the last few years is that I see more people with higher grades than ever before, but more dick for brain than I've ever seen. Sometimes this stupidity hurts. this is the reason we've interviews, and so I can filter that out.. Ultimately, I don't see much price in a A* university degree, nor in tens of certificates. Whenever I see 20 students in an assessment centre, it's easy to tell those that got there by wasting hours inside library and which ones got truth be told there by sheer intellect.  Obviously once you hire a group of students, you will do choose one regarding the blind work ethic like a horse graduates. Because sometimes you want to hang out with people who aren't that bright, just to see how the other half lives.

Grades in school do not necessarily reflect your intelligence.  A grade in a subject correlates better to how much you've learned about that subject than to how smart you are.  Grades are also a result of hard work, and support at home, and the quality of teaching.  (Let's not stop to argue about how teachers should be evaluated.)   But, people who don't know you will assume that bad grades mean you aren't smart, or aren't disciplined, or that you are lazy.  Whatever the actual reasons, bad grades will likely reduce your opportunities.  Similarly, good grades may get strangers to give you a little more attention.  That doesn't guarantee success, but it's an extra opportunity. And more of life than we'd like to admit depends on whether you have more or fewer opportunities.

Yes, they accurately reflect one’s IQ, and quite to a large extent. The general factor of intelligence (g) accounts for over 30% of the variance in school grades, being, moreover, the best single predictor of school achievement social sciences have ever produced. Reportedly, the correlation between Intelligence, as measured by standardized tests, and school success stands at around .56[1]. Frankly speaking, I guess that’s self-evident and should not require further investigation — you have to be blue-pilled to deny such a clear relationship[2]. Do not get misled by all those saying conscientiousness, motivation, etc. are what solely mediate the difference in school performances among students. Even though they do matter, on the whole, they are not nearly as statistically significant as IQ is. Footnotes[1] Intelligence and school grades: A meta-analysis[2] Jordan Peterson: Is intelligence the most important factor in determining university success?

Intelligence is supposedly innate — that is, you are born with the level of power you possess to reason and to figure out things. Not everybody otherwise intelligent applies themselves to scholarly pursuits, though. So there may be considerable dissonance between one’s measures of intelligence and measures of scholarship. Then there is memory. Memory is the ability to recall things you have seen before. Some people are very good at memorizing. But memory is not the same as intelligence. Though memory alone can help one achieve better grades, it doesn’t necessarily help one figure out something new. So, no, grades do not determine intelligence, and often intelligent people don’t make good grades — for many reasons, such as lack of interest, lack of respect for the scholarly environment, other interests, and such.

What do grades say about one’s intelligence? I’m talking about high-school grades I like to say upfront that my understanding of intelligence is deeply influenced by Dr Howard Gardner, Dr Robert Sternberg and Dr Raymond Cattell. As a result, I hold the explicit view that a person’s intelligence boils down to his ability and capacity to learn, acquire, and adapt to problem-solve in his everyday life and/or workflow activities. So when I look at your question, I want to say that grades have something to do with intelligence. As an efficient and effective student, you invariably need your intelligence to: grasp the importance of your own personal future, by understanding your own current problems, and your plans to deal with them, while traversing the academic trajectory;explore ways to acquire and practise proven study tools and productivity hacks to help resolve your own problems, but more importantly, to enable you to navigate your academic journey with ease, expediency and ace;select the right tools and strategies to work in your student life, so as to attain eventually good grades in school, but more importantly, to put yourself in a robust position to have more educational options in your favour;In nut shell, your academic success hinges on your intelligent and diligent efforts.

Don't we all wish life were this simple? Grades in school represent a number of traits, only one of which is intelligence.  In fact, I have always maintained that conscientiousness is a better predictor of GPA than raw intelligence in most disciplines that one studies.  My friends in physics would dispute this, claiming that no amount of hard work will cover up a lack of sheer brainpower, but most areas are more about hard work than brainpower. I had a professor challenge the class of the calculus class I took as part of a graduate degree challenge us: get a 93% average on all work and you could skip the final.  I went out and bought a second calc. book and did all of the problems in both the text and in a second book and was one of two students in a class of 40 to meet the standard.  And it had nothing to do with my math intelligence.  I just worked. Given the choice between talent and tenacity, I believe that tenacity always wins.

A bit but not fairly, it does access their ability to prepare or preform well for testing, it does not truly depict ability or intelligence unless the test can not be studied for and requires one to learn, process and complete a task or perform a function they taught themselves. I tested poorly early on until I learned to memorize everything the night before getting little sleep, I tend to overthink and when I am tired I just answer, that and having memorized everything made testing quite effortless. This does not prove my intelligence, only that I found a method that works for me.

As you say you are in a “High school” where we are usually taught that gardes determine intellectual level of an individual. See, as you will grow and purse your college , you will see that there is a flaw in this system. I dont say that grades don't matter at all. Yes , they do matter but they are NOT the “only” creteria to judge your intellectual level. You need to be conceptually cleared with the subject. Maybe at times you are not able to give your 100 percent. This can be due to lack of confidence or some other reason. Its okay to score low at times. But try to figure out where are YOU lacking . Making mistakes in the school tests make you learn that you don't have to make the same mistake again in the final exams. Don't feel guilty rather figure it out and work on it. If it is the time problem, then try to have mock tests. Increase your practice. And never fear from a question specially in maths. Its all the same . Study to learn first and then to score. Grades gonna vary but concept is forever. So, focus more on the concept first and then find why can't u score.

Universities think that High School Grades determine whether or not you are capable of graduating from their university. All this educational philosophical studies on grades and abilities and multiple intelligence does not matter at all. Why? Universities do not care at all! They want you to score the highest grade in school and on their arbitrary entrance exams, and write the perfect writing example, and have the right extra-curricular activities. They could care less that you are a over achieving person who’s area of savantness is in Sociology. They don’t want your kind. They want only the best of the very best. Grades only really say how good you are at taking tests. They are rubbish in reality, but yet, Universities think they are “God” at determining ability.

No they definitely do not. Grades are determined by how much one studies and completes work. A good example of this would be Bill Gates, he had average grades in high school and never finished college yet he managed to revolutionize the computer industry not to mention found one of the largest computer companies in the world. He is currently the wealthiest person in the world with a 84.2 billion net worth and with his investments he makes around $114 every second he is alive. He is also known to have a near perfect photographic memory.

They reflect it, but not all that well.   There is no general agreement on exactly what intelligence means; however, pretty much everyone agrees that it is multifaceted.  Some of those facets are very useful for school work (and different facets will be more useful for different courses).  For example, most theories of intelligence would include various aspects of memory as part of intelligence and having a good memory is certainly useful for school. However, schoolwork also reflects: 1) How much you study2) How well you study3) Whether teachers like you4) Penmanship and so on. And (depending on your definition of intelligence) some aspects of intelligence may not be related to grades (or, at least, only weakly related).

No, grades do not define a person’s intelligence. My dad scored 60% in HSC(2nd attempt), flunked a year in diploma making him study again. Ended up the course luckily, by barely scoring passing marks in each semester by the grace of God and his friends. But what my dad always did was, he kept gaining practical knowledge at every stage of his life. He knew very well how to handle people and persuade them for a favor. He kept getting better at it. Though he couldn’t understand Technical terms, he was very strong in understanding human terms. He knew very well how to get his job done. He developed a very strong sense of logic. He did struggle initially but today he handles the HR division of his company and works very hard and passionately. He counsels people who find themselves mentally disturbed, and helps them to lead a wonderful life. One day the topper of his diploma batch, met him and shockingly he was still struggling to stand firm in this competitive world. Hence grades do not define a person’s intelligence. Every man is born with certain talents and strengths, he who discovers them succeed. To discover our talent you need to work hard and smart.

Grades don't reflect intelligence, they reflect your ability to accomplish a task within the parameters and guidelines you are given. I have taught and worked with some very intelligent people whose grades don't reflect it. I have taught and worked with people I would say are dumb as bricks but have outstanding grades. On the whole, grades can be a quick indication of intelligence, since there tends to be a correlation, but I would never want to measure my self worth based on grades.

No! Never…….Grades can never define an intelligent person. Because there is something which is wrong with our education system. It checks our memory you rather than checking our intelligence. Me and my mom, just 2 minutes before we both were discussing on this topic. Our conversation went something like this: Mom: Today your dad was complaining about you. Me: What did I do? Mom: He said that he never saw you studying. Me: Really!? Mom: Yes Me: Oh! So tell me from where I got the Grades? Mom: Your Grades were not so good OK! Me: Mom Grades don't matter. That is the intelligence of a person which is going to shape their future and Thomas Edison said,” Tomorrow is my exam, but I don't care because a single sheet of paper cannot decide my future.” Mom: Leave it. You just know how to talk all day! As you can see I tried a lot to explain my mom but what all she wants from me is just good grades. Your marks can't explain how intelligent you are! So never loose hopes, never think about what people say, just do what you want to do!!

Grades don’t determine intelligence but they are a way for you to prove to the outside world that you are intelligent. And as regards, you running out of time in maths exam is concerned you must be lacking practice or you must not have done proper time management that you were not able to complete the paper. I am talking about school papers and not competitions like rmo etc. School papers are designed in such a way that one can complete the whole paper if he/she has prepared well. But what is bygones be bygones. Don’t be dejected about it. Everybody commits mistakes. But the real crux lies in how one is able to learn from these mistakes and improve oneself. If you keep on learning and improving on whatever silly mistakes you do in school exam, a time would come when you become nearly perfect and then you would clear exams like jee etc and become successful.

Grades Determines Your KNOWLEDGE About the subject. When we consider the Normal school subjects like Language, History, Geography,s science etc. are all informative subjects. To score good grades in those subject requires quite good memory and bit dedication and Intelligence never matters . The only subject I will say is bit depending upon Intelligence is math. Hence most of the students dont like math. In such case where for scoring good grades Intelligence never play any role and main factors are memory and dedication. We can say that Grades never determine Intelligence. BTW, I never had good grades throughout my school Life but I am working in India's largest and Among the world's best Construction company…. Well I had huge score in engineering math (Thirty Two out of Eighty ) 32/80.\U0001f61b

No. A smart person might have poor grades for various reasons. For example: They’re taking subjects that are wrong for them. A person who is not so gifted in Subjects A to E, but is taking them nonetheless, might get poor marks despite lots of effort. The same person might be very gifted in Subjects F to O though, and could do phenomenally if they switched to some of those. (It’s deliberate that the person has more subjects at which they are gifted than ungifted).They have poor teachers who teach in a fashion that doesn’t suit the student.They have a bad memory…and are taking closed book exams. A person who has a good memory but is not intelligent can learn Facts A to G. But they can’t tell you what other facts must be true if those facts are. Nor can they see that, actually, there is no way that all those facts can be true because C and G are inconsistent. An intelligent person with a bad memory, but with their textbooks and notes can see that.They have other concerns. Like a bad home life. Or maybe they need to work a part time job because that is the only way they can afford college/university.

No, I think grades doesn’t exactly defines intelligence of a person, instead, I would say that grades define obedience of a person. Why? It because ordinary people could also get a good grades when they’re hardworking, obedient with the rules, and do all of the assignments given. However, it couldn’t be denied as well that intelligence people obviously is gifted with ability to comprehend new materials quite easily thus making it fairly easy for them to get good grades (unless they’re really lazy and not putting work upon it).

No grades doesn’t determine your intelligence. Your intelligence can be determined based on several things like art, dance, sport, entertainment, science etc. There is no particular field or area in which your intelligence can be measured. Intelligence covers everything like what we do in our daily life, our profession and passion. And for your case it is okay if your are not able to solve every math problem because nobody is perfect. If you really want to be said intelligent then develop something which would help people in their daily life, something exceptional and very helpful then you will be praised as intelligent for years.

I’ve thought about this question a lot. For me, I care about my grades like a mother would care for her children. So, I try my best to get good grades and put in a lot of effort. Even though I have one of the highest GPAs in my Middle School, I know a lot of students who are better than me at various subjects like math, but they don’t care about their grades as much. I would say that I’m good at math, but am pretty slow. Also, others may know the techniques of appealing to teachers (participating, helping out, knowing what a teacher expects on an essay, etc). To sum things up, grades do not fully determine your intelligence.

Not much! How do I know? My report cards use to come back with notes that read something like this: "I don't know why Cortland doesn't get better grades; he's so smart." I would eventually – many years later – learn that this was due to high functioning autism, for which I was even then a developing a work-around. As I recall correctly, my Sophmore biology teacher sent back a slightly different note about halfway through the year. "I don't know how he does it. He never takes notes." In THAT class I had gotten hold of some college biology texts and in lieue of a good memory and good study habits, I read them, as well as the High School text, several times.

Grade, so basically you are one of those who thinks about the same question in their mind during their academics. Yes and No both are the answer for you, because if you have already started to think from your high schooling about ups and downs in your grades or points than you seems to be in trouble. Please don't think much about grades. It will only leads you in comparison. This comparison will further take you into the ocean of fears. No matter how much grades you achieve, your mind can never be satisfied and keep on comparing it. And there is no end of comparison so my personal suggestion is don't mess with this grades or points or marks in your studies. Just focus over your favourite subjects, the subject you love to study work hard over it. Only two factors about grades in academics I am describing here. The grades will help only external people to indicate the level of your intellect.The grades will not help you to define at which level exactly your intellect stands.Now it's upto you which factor of grades you focus most importantly.

I don't think that grades determine a person's intelligence for example a person could be good at something other than studies like playing guitar or sketching or any other things that doesn't mean he/she is dumb, that means that his/her interest is in something other than studies and can excel in that if not in studies that means that person is intelligent in a different way This is a myth now these days that grades are everything. I am bit against this notion not totally because grade too mean something to a person academic performance …… So I'll say cherish what you are good at and never give up on your dreams Hope it helps :)

The word “class” is a bit ambiguous. I am going to take it to mean student body class, as in elementary and high school “class” results. That leads to two measures of student performance, grades and achievement test results. We used both of those, individually and together to determine those students who might be Gifted. So, a student that gets all “A”s all the time might well be tested for Gifted services. More likely is the result of nationwide achievement test results, those are also a part of the determination of need for services. You must score at the 95th percentile or higher on an accepted nationwide normed test in two or more areas (say, Reading and Math) as well as score at the 97th percentile on an ability test (either 128 or 130, dependent on the test used) as well as have a NEED for services to be placed in Gifted services. There are exceptions but not very far from these requirements.

Nope. It exemplifies hard work and nothing more. In high school, I was one of the smart kids but didn't want to put in the effort, hard work, and dedication that those with good grades did. I knew I was smart (even smarter than some with the better grades) which was proven on standardized tests and college entrance exams. When you can score higher on said tests (frequently) than those with better grades, it proves intelligence (ability to quickly recall what you've learned).

Tests don't test how smart you are. They only test what material you can remember, like a memory test. Other tests like the SAT only test how good you are at taking that specific test.Our current schooling system are flawed because they were designed to be based on something called the Prussian education system which was meant to produce factory workers, or people who are good at following directions and not necessarily good at learning.How good you are in school has nothing to do with intelligence, only with how good you are at being an obedient student.

Do grades determine intelligence? You’ve framed your question in such a way that it sounds as if you are asking this question: do grades cause intelligence? The answer: an emphatic NO. Higher grades are suggestive of greater than average intelligence. Classroom grades (K-12) or college are also determined by other factors, but especially amount of time “cracking the books,” i.e., studying.

No. I am also in high school and tried to get all honors classes this year, I almost had a panic attack. (Due to some really stressful class last year which actually caused this problem) I wanted to do this because I felt like I was belittled as all my friends were so good with grades, and all that jazz. After a sabbatical one tiny break, I realized I’m smart in many ways. It may not reflect to certain subjects but, it shined when ever I do any to that subject related. I loved to write poetry, speeches, and act. I loved it and was great at it. Don’t let these grades reflect how good you are in those subjects. Explore yourself, you may be a master at something else. :)

If I consider grades determine intelligence , then there would be argument that there are many people who do not have good grades but they are intelligent. If I consider grades do not determine intelligence, then there will be argument that there are many people who have good grades and also intelligent. Actual fact is that there are several factors which all together trigger intelligence in human being. Effect of grades is less compared to other factors. To conclude i would say don’t derive intelligence from grades and also don’t ignore the grades by considering it as less important factor.Both of them have their own value and that can be realised each and every stages of our life.

Yes and no. Academic intelligence is measured by grades. IQ measures only linguistic and mathematical intelligences- which are just two in the theory of multiple intelligences. The intelligences unrelated to grades are musical, spatial, kinesthetic, interpersonal, intrapersonal, pedagogical, naturalistic and existential intelligences. Another way is to classify intelligences into general, social, practical, emotional, personal and academic intelligences. Grades relate to only the last item in the list.

No, they don’t. Even people say that is related but in my opinion is not that much related. I graduate from college with mediocre grade, It took 10 month to finish my undergraduate thesis and I was the last in the final exam. My final exam was really easy by the way. Why I took so long to finish my thesis? It was because my thesis is the most difficult among the others. Why my grades is so so? I don’t know, I got A if the subject was difficult but if the subject was easy, I only got B or even C.

NO! They determine your memory not your intelligence. The tests you are given in school, determine how good you are at remembering things not how intelligent you are. I am quite intelligent myself and I decide what my grades are like. If I am interested I will apply myself and get good marks. If I think it is a waste of time I will flunk it. One last thing no matter what you hear from teachers or parents, about them comparing you to others or saying that grades will determine if you are successful or not. They don’t!

Grades reflect a lot of things, only one of which is intelligence. OTTOMH, it would be a combination of intelligence, study, interest, aptitude and compliance, minus things like hand-eye-coordination, dyslexia, home situation, romantic relationships; things like teaching and parenting can be a positive or a negative. So if you have low intelligence, but _fantastic_ other factors, you may still get good grades. Or you have high intelligence, but some of your other factors suck, you’re not going to get good grades.

Not necessarily. But grades do reflect your ability to exhibit your intelligence in performing well in an exam. you know how to solve that left out problem, so every thing boils down to just efficient time management. Time management plays a crucial role in achieving success in any time bound exam. Certainly, losing track of time is a mistake committed, try not to repeat it next time. At the end of the day, what matters is how you feel about yourself.Don't be too harsh on yourself. Mistakes do happen, learning from them should also happen. All the best for future exams ……there are lot more to come.

NO. Theses things only measure your knowledge as of right now. One day, you might have an intellectual conversation with a friend and the next you're struggling with Algebra II. School and grades are just what you show on the outside, not what you know on the inside.

Grades REFLECT a person's intelligence in two ways: Ability to achieve the scores, intellectual intelligence.Ability to put up with the bullshit, emotional intelligence. A shortcoming of grades is that they cannot define an intelligence that would be expressed by a class you have taken. If you have no grade in Music, you might play like Paganini, or you might sing like a frog, how would I know?
They are an accurate representation of one's belief in the grading system. Nothing more.

There are different types of intelligence, but if you’re talking IQ, there is a strong correlation to mathematics and consequently to science and to a lesser degree other subjects. If you have a high IQ, you will be good at mathematics. How good depends on how hard and intelligently you study, how good your teachers were and the mind set you take towards maths. If you have a low IQ, you can become relatively good at mathematics through hard work and practice, but it won’t come naturally to you like it can do to some people with a high IQ, and you will never become a genius. Hard work carries you a long way (further than people realise), but those with a natural intelligence in something have a huge advantage.

No, not at all. Thomas Edison was told that he was too stupid to learn anything. Only if you get bad grades doesn't means that you are not intelligent, and success has nothing to do with grades. A man was once fired from his job by saying that he didn't have creativity, this man WAS NONE OTHER THAN WALT DISNEY

The difficulty of classes taken in high school are a greater indicator of intelligence than grades, which is why many schools use weighted grades. But nation-wide exams (AP, SAT, ACT) are still what colleges place much of their emphasis on in determining which students are likely succeed. Typically people within the upper ten to twenty percent (according to grades) includes the most intelligent students, but the actually ranked is often skewed by students that simply understand how to please the teachers.

No, No, And No Grades don’t do so, Do you know how people get grades? Just by memorizing (Byhearting)… Let’s take an example of the subject computer… You will byheart the answer to the question “What is copy-paste?” You will byheart and get full marks, but in real life, you will not be going to know what is copy-paste…. Grades determine how much you can remember…. Bill Gates used to get F in the exam, and his friends made fun of him… Now, the toppers in his class earn less than $100,000 per year…. But Bill Gates, who got F, earns $ 4 BILLION

Not absolutely. However, more unintelligent people than intelligent people get low grades. So grades are "markers" that help people, like employers, find people who are likely to be smart.If you are smart but get poor grades, make extra efforts to document the other achievements that demonstrate your competence, and get that evidence in front of people who you want to impress.

Since intelligence's best measure is IQ, and there is a 0.2 correlation between IQ and grades, NO, grades in school do not determine your intelligence. Your working memory capacity (short-term memory; how many bits of info you can have in your head) is the largest factor in your IQ.

The above question has not a single answer. It depends from person to person. Some people give intelligence as their priority while some go with the grades. Your problem is very specific. You might be good at solving maths questions and puzzles. While you might not be that quick to get the solution or your writing pace may be low. So now you know that you have an interest in mathematics, so use this point to its full. Solving questions at home and in exams are two different situations. If possible create an examination like environment at home itself and try doing questions in a particular time limit. It will help you developing skills which tend to play small roles in big situations.

grades don’t determine intelligence. if grade decide then we don’t need interviews. I felt the same in my school days. I used to solve the tough problems in the exam and then rest of the time for the easy ones. You definitely get recognition for that. Since you are a high school student, you know who much important is the grades. Your question may not be even relevant for higher studies, but grades do matter for higher studies.

If there is a relationship, it would more likely be the other way around - intelligence determines grades. But since a lot more goes into getting good grades than raw intelligence (hard work, good study habits, etc), even then the relationship is probably weak.

Absolutely not. I grade people all the time. It’s a big part of my job. Years ago, however, I learned that grades are just a “snapshot,” usually, of anyone’s performance. They don’t adequately measure intelligence. At best, grades measure a certain degree of aptitude and one’s ability to perform, in certain ways, until certain restrictions. I never judge a student’s “intelligence” based on a metric as imperfect as grades.

No. Scholastic aptitude testing can only measure your ability to conform to the standards of said tests and your determination to conform to said test standards at the time you are taking it. They are useless for pretty much anything else. And they are especially worthless, if the subject tested isn't motivated to do so, or even has special reservations against it.

Haha.... never.....Issac Newton, Einstein and many other scientists all got very poor grades. For life, the right side(creative) is more important.  But unfortunately all major companies opt for left mined people(analitycal) so that they obey orders and carry out instructions word by word.

No, you earn grades through tests that show you can either memorize a lot, or you understood what was taught. They don’t prove you are intelligent. Now after you have learned something if you can expand on it, or produce something from the knowledge, that proves intelligence.

Einstein is said to have done poorly in school. I agree with what a previous answer said - grades measure your performance in school. Grades don't measure - nor are they intended to be a measure - of intelligence.

No, it is only a reflection of what you have understood from what you have been taught. Intelligence is different. It is weighing pros and cons and reacting to an impending situation or proactive to something which is coming.
I agree with the previous two answers. You can have more degrees than a thermometer and you know where that goes

No. Genes determine the blueprint you will be born to try and match. Mutations in the womb will modify that blueprint. The environment you are born into will determine your behavior, which determines what potentials you live up to and which ones you fail at. Which of these you consider intelligence, is up to you.
no. grade doesn’t determine intelligence but having higher grades will help you to have options as much as you can. Such as - normal eligibility criteria in any field is min. 65 and above.

Surely not . Einstein failed five times in class because he doesn't liked any other subjects except maths. In fact many geniuses have opposing views on exams.At last this quote of a genius is enough to answer this question -"One sheet of paper can't decide my future".

I believe so, Because i used to be dumb and dont care about education but i stopped and start asking questions and asking teachers for help and start studying a little bit and now i think im smart with a lot of intelligence,….. if ur failing 4 and 5 subjects and u think u hv intelligence that means ur dumb…. Intelligence is not like an app u cant download it you have to code it and use it…..

Intelligence is diverse and it extends to all fields of human endeavor. If an insanely talented singer scores a D minus for math, then considering her as non-intelligent is unfair. That being said, a good grade in math may not always be indicative of a person’s intelligence or even a reasonable quantitative aptitude as most of our testing methods today favor the candidate who is more naturalized to the exam rather than the subject.
